I. 

INTRODUCTION 

through 

the  Australian  Agency 

from  Government  of  Australia 

1. 
The  Solomon  Islands  Second  Road  Improvement  (Sector)  Project  (SIRIP  2)  was 
approved  on  12  November  2009.1  The  total  cost  of  the  project  is  $24.00  million  and  it  will  be 
financed  by  a  $15.00  million  grant  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  a  $4.50  million 
grant 
International 
Development (AusAID), a $3.34 million grant from the European Commission, and $1.16 million 
equivalent  from  the  Government  of  Solomon  Islands.  The  conditions  of  effectiveness  of  the 
ADB2  grant  were  met  by  the  government  and  the  grant  was  declared  effective  on  10  March 
2010. The project is expected to close on 31 March 2012. 
 
This  paper  seeks  approval  of  the  administration  by  ADB  of  new  cofinancing  grants 
2. 
offered by the Governments of Australia (A$300,000) and New Zealand (NZ$500,000) through 
their  international  development  agencies.  These  new  funds  have  been  offered  for  the 
restoration  of  damaged  transport  infrastructure  in  west  Guadalcanal  caused  by  a  series  of 
floods  between  January  and  March  2010.  The  restoration  of  damaged  infrastructure  will  re-
connect  a  population  of  about  12,000  people  in  west  Guadalcanal  to  food,  medical  supplies, 
schools, markets, and urban centers.  
 

for 

II. 

BACKGROUND 

3. 
SIRIP 2 aims to benefit about 41,000 people directly and to enhance the incomes of the 
poor  and  rural  population.  The  project  impact  is  expected  to  be  economic  growth  and  social 
development  and  a  reduction  in  hardship  and  poverty.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  road 
transport  for  economic  and  social  activities.  Outputs  will  include  (i) an  improved  network  of 
national, provincial, and secondary roads; (ii) sound and sustainable road maintenance policies 
and practices; and (iii) more participation by communities and women in road maintenance. Key 
activities will include (i) replacing or upgrading about 30 water crossings (bridges, culverts, and 
wet  crossings);  (ii)  building  about  20  kilometers  (km)  of  associated  bridge  approaches,  and,  if 
necessary,  relocating  sections  of  roads  for  climate  change  adaptation;  (iii)  upgrading  and 
sealing 10 km of road to prevent the loss of pavement materials during heavy rain and floods; 
(iv)  community  participation  in  road  maintenance;  and  (v)  continued  capacity  building  begun 
under  the  Solomon  Islands  Road  Improvement  (Sector)  Project  (SIRIP)  3   for  national  staff, 
consultants, and contractors. 
 
SIRIP 2 has two components: (i) civil works (road rehabilitation, road maintenance labor-
4. 
based, equipment-support methods and road maintenance); and (ii) consulting services (design 
and  supervision,  project  management  and  capacity  building).  The  Ministry  of  Infrastructure 
Development (MID) is the executing agency for the project. The project is being implemented in 
Guadalcanal and Malaita provinces and, where funds allow, will also be extended to the seven 
other provinces, all of which have had insufficient investment in the past.4

 2 

 

 
5. 
Between  January  and  March  2010,  torrential  rain  and  flood  waters  damaged  bridge 
approaches  on  west  Guadalcanal  roads,  disconnecting  the  road  at  several  locations  from  the 
capital, Honiara and severely disrupting transport services. The cost of reinstating the road and 
bridge  works,  including  consultancy  services  for  design  and  supervision,  is  approximately  
$0.60 million. Because of a lack of funding, the Government of Solomon Islands, through MID, 
requested its donor partners to assist with the required funds. 
 
In  response  to  MID's  request,  the  Government  of  Australia  through  AusAID  committed 
6. 
A$300,000  and  the  Government  of  New  Zealand  through  the  New  Zealand  Agency  for 
International  Development  (NZAID)  committed  NZ$500,000  to  reinstate  the  road  to  restore 
connectivity at the affected areas. The total additional funding amounts to $637,9945 and both 
AusAID  and  NZAID  have  requested  that  funds  be  specifically  used  to  restore  access  to  the 
12,000  people  who  have  been  cut  off.  These  funds  will  be  used  to  restore  connections  and 
include  the  costs  of  the  civil  works,  consulting  services,  audit,  bank  charges  and  ADB's  5% 
administration fee. The additional funds will increase the overall project cost from $24,000,000 
to $24,637,994, an increase of 2.7%. The increase in overall project costs and the expansion of 
scope  of  works  constitutes  a  minor  change  in  scope.  ADB,  as  the  lead  donor  in  transport 
infrastructure  in  the  Solomon  Islands,  will  administer  the  AusAID  and  NZAID  grants.  MID  will 
procure  all  works  and  goods  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time) and will engage consultants in accordance with ADB's  Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the grants 
administered by ADB will be disbursed through direct payment in accordance with ADB's Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time). The detailed cost estimates by 
financier are attached as the Appendix.  
 

III. 

THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 

I  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  on  a  no  objection  basis  (i)  the  administration  by 
7. 
ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  A$300,000  to  Solomon  Islands  to  be  provided  by  the 
Government  of  Australia;  and  (ii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding 
NZ$500,000  to  Solomon  Islands  to  be  provided  by  the  Government  of  New  Zealand,  in  both 
cases for the Second Road Improvement (Sector) Project.
